transcript: by a superior enemy force as a result of one of these maneuvers that en- abled us to escape him. Buxhowden pursues us we scuttle. He hardly crosses the river to our side before we recross to the other. At last our enemy, Buxhowden, catches us and attacks. Both generals are angry, and the result is a challenge on Buxhowden's part and an epilep- tic fit on Bennigsen's. But at the critical mo- ment the courier who carried the news of our victory at Pulttisk to Petersburg returns bring- ing
